bibl.title: Letter from Oliver L. Pothier to Joseph H. White, June 14, 1923

div1.p: Pothier reports on his trip to Cucuta, Colombia, where no yellow fever is reported, although there is a great incidence of stegomyia. He has informed the government of the necessity for a mosquito campaign.

div1.head: Letter from Oliver L. Pothier to Joseph H. White, June 14, 1923
div1.opener:
N. I. H. B.
Colombia
C O P Y
LOYOLA UNIVERSITY
Department of
BACTERIOLOGY AND CLINICAL LABORATORY
New Orleans, La.,
Cucuta, June 14th, 1923
Dr. J. H. White,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
We arrived here yesterday, in the evening, June the thirteenth,
after a delayed voyage from Baranquilla. We were delayed two days in
Curacao, leaving there on Saturday, June the tenth, and arriving in Maracaibo
Sunday, the eleventh. As we could not leave Maracaibo until the following
Thursday, by the weekly mail boat, we chartered a small tug boat which took
us to Encontrados. Leaving Maracaibo at one A.M. Tuesday, June the twelfth,
we arrived at Encontrados Wednesday morning the Thirteenth. From Encontrados,
due to the kindness of the President of the State of Zulia, a special train
was put at our disposal to take us to Tachira Station, from whence we came
to Cucuta in automobile.

This morning, in company of the Chief of Hygiene, we visited the
hospital, which we found free from yellow fever or any suspicious cases.
After we called on the Governor, in whose company we visited the Barracks
infirmary, which we also found free from yellow fever or suspicious cases.
From the report of several of the physicians, whom we met, and who were very
cordial, we obtained the information that there were no cases in the city of
a suspicious nature. On the other hand they informed us of the great inci-
dence of stegomyia, a fact which we verified by personal observation.

When we called on the Governor we impressed the necessity of
mosquito campaign, on account of the proximity to Bucaramanga, and of the
danger of infection. At the request of the Governor, we agreed to sign a
telegram to the National Chief of Hygiene, concerning the status of Cucu-
ta, and our recommendation of a mosquito campaign. This telegram was a
joint one to Dr. P. Garcia Medina, and Dr. F. A. Miller, and sent from the
office of the Governor, after having been signed by Dr. W. Pareja and Dr.
C. L. Pothier.

This completes our mission to Cucuta. We are leaving tomorrow
afternoon, June the fifteenth, on our return to Maracaibo, and thence to
Curacao, to take the earliest steamer to Colon, from which we respectively
will return home.

In Maracaibo we were extended a courteous and cordial reception
by the President of the State of Zulia, through the offices of Drs. Aranguren
and Irarazabal, respectively Port Physician and Inspector of Customs, and
the Secretary General of the State. After this cordial reception we sent
a telegram of thanks to the President of the Republic which was duly acknow-
ledged. Here in Cucuta the Governor and other officials, and physicians
were cordiality itself.

Trusting that this report will meet with your approval, we wish
to remain,
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) Dr. O. L. Pothier Dr. W. Paraja
(Original to Dr. J. H. White)
(Copies to Drs. Paraja and Pothier).
